title: "What is man and why is he considered a machine according to Gurdjieff's teachings?"
first_phrase: This text explores the idea of human nature and our individuality, highlighting the teachings of Gurdjieff-1. The author argues that humans are not a permanent unity but rather continuously evolving and changing. The first step in this realization is becoming aware of our own mechanistic nature, of how external stimuli shape our thoughts, beliefs, and actions. The text highlights the complexity of truly understanding why we do what we do, as our choices are a product of our inherited predispositions, habits, and subconscious motivations. The last 200 tokens delve deeper into how our "atavisms" shape us and how this knowledge can help us break free from our mechanical ways.

last_phrase: In conclusion, according to Gurdjieff, we are the product of our environment and circumstances. Our actions are often influenced by unconscious habits and external factors, and it's rare for us to identify the real reason behind them. Therefore, it's essential to self-analyze regularly and be aware of our automatic behaviors to make conscious decisions and break free from our limiting atavisms.
